entry.title: XAFS Theory
entry.content:
XAFS is an element-specific spectroscopy in which measurements are made by tuning the X-ray energy at and above a selected core-level binding energy of a specified element. Although XAFS is a well-established technique providing reliable and useful information about the chemical and physical environment of the probe atom, its requirement of an energytunable X-ray source means it is primarily done with synchrotron radiation sources and so is somewhat less common than other spectroscopic analytical methods. XAFS spectra are especially sensitive to the oxidation state and coordination chemistry of the selected element.

entry.title: Use Dioptas for Efficient 2D Powder Diffraction Data Reduction
entry.content:
Dioptas is an awesome GUI program based on Python, designed for the fast data reduction of Powder X-ray Diffraction images. It provides the capability of calibrating, integrating, creating masks, showing multiple pattern overlays and display phases line positions.

Program dependencies

Distribution

Maintainer

Clemens Prescher (clemens.prescher@gmail.com)

Installation

Executables

Binary programs for Windows, macOS, and Linux can be downloaded from the following link:

pip

Install the all the dependencies for Dioptas by pip package manager:

poetry
Use the poetry package manager to create a working environment by typing:

Procedure

Overview

Dioptas has three different modules which can all be accessed by the lab indicators on the left side of the user interface: Calibration, Mask, Integration.

  • Calibration Module This module is used to calibrate the detector geometry.
  • Mask Module This module allows users to select regions that need to be excluded from the image integration.
  • Integration Module This module displays the image and integrated pattern. It can overlay different patterns and show the line positions of phases.

Getting Started

Basic Mouse Operations

  • Left Drag
  • Right Click
  • Right Double Click
  • Mouse Wheel
  • Left Drag Zooms into the selected area.
  • Right Click Zoom out.
  • Right Double Click Completely Zoom out.
  • Mouse Wheel Zoom in and zoom out based on the current cursor position.

Image Color Scale and Contrast

The image color scale and contrast can be adjusted by sliding the color bar and right-clicking to change the color group.

Workflow

flowchart LR
    A(Load Image Data) -->B(Calibration)
    B --> C(Mask)
    C --> D(Integration)
    D --> E(Export Data)
    D -->A

Let's start by loading the image data.
Click the button the on the upper right side of the interface to begin the process.

Calibration Procedure

The callibration procedure aim to correct the detector geometry.

Preparation

First, click the button located on the left side of the window to enter calibration mode.
The wavelength and pixel width/height have to be defined based on the experimental setup and detector used.

Required Parameter Setting:

  • Calibrant (standard complex)
  • wavelength
  • pixel width
  • pixel height
  • Distance (the program will automatically refine the value)

Peak Picking

After selecting the 'Calibration Parameter', Dioptas requires an initial guess for the ring positions to determine the correct geometry. Select several points on each diffraction ring to proceed.
If the default automatic peak search is enabled, simply left-click the first diffraction ring as shown in this figure. Zooming in on the image will help accurately target the first ring.

If the automatic peak searching fails, you can try the following alternatives:

  • Perform the automatic search on the second, third, or subsequent rings.
  • Choose the single peak search option.
